data.title: Holland, MI
data.meta_description: General Elections are held every year on the first Tuesday between November 2 and 8.
data.text:
2024 Elections

February 27 - Presidential Primary

May 7 - Special Election for Voters in the Hamilton Community School District only (part of Ward 5, Precinct 11)

Absentee ballots available; NO early voting because it is not a statewide election

August 6 - Primary Election - voting in one party only, to choose 1 candidate for each office, except the President

November 5 - Presidential Election

Choice of 3 ways to vote for State and Federal Elections

Choose the method and location that works best for you!

√ Vote In Person

Polls will be open on Election Day from 7:00 am - 8:00 pm. Polling locations are listed below.

Please take a photo ID to the polls.

√ Vote at an Ottawa County Early Voting Center

Voters will have nine additional days prior to each state and federal election where they may cast their ballot just as they would on Election Day. Four locations will be utilized in 2024 as Early Vote Centers in Ottawa County. All City of Holland voters may vote at these locations (even if you live in the Allegan County portion of the City).

Locations:

• NE: Polkton Township Hall: 6900 Arthur St., Coopersville

• SE: Georgetown Township Hall: 1515 Baldwin St., Jenison

• NW: Grand Haven Township Hall: 13300 168th Ave., Grand Haven

• SW: MDHHS Building Macatawa Room: 12185 James St., Holland

Hours:

•Saturday: 7AM-3PM

•Sunday: 7AM-3PM

•Monday: 7AM-3PM

•Tuesday: 11AM-7PM

•Wednesday: 7AM-3PM

•Thursday: 11AM-7PM

•Friday: 7AM-3PM

•Saturday: 7AM-3PM

•Sunday: 7AM-3PM

•Monday: No Early Voting

•Tuesday: Election Day - Vote at your precinct

Voters will be receiving additional Early Voting information by mail or visit www.miottawa.org/EarlyVoting.

√ Vote by Absentee Ballot

Sign and date an application and return it to the City Clerk personnel in the City Hall Lobby.

Applications are available on our website at the Absentee Voting tab at the upper left of this page or by going to michigan.gov/vote.

Additional Hours for Voter Registration and Absentee Ballot Requests

The City Clerk's office will be open the Saturday before each election from 7:00 am - 3:00 pm to register voters and issue absentee ballots.

Please remember to take your photo ID to the polling place or to the Clerk’s office when requesting a ballot.

View Your Ballot

Check out what's on your ballot here.

Annual Elections

General Elections are held every year on the first Tuesday between November 2 and 8. In addition, Local or State elections may take place during the year: there is usually an election the first Tuesday between August 2 and 8, sometimes an election in May, and Presidential Primaries in February of Presidential Election years.

The City Clerk’s office oversees all elections in the City of Holland, working in coordination with the Ottawa County and Allegan County Clerks. All election results can be found on the Ottawa County Clerk’s website.

Wards & Precincts

The City of Holland is divided into 6 Wards, which are made up of 13 Precincts. The City limits span parts of both Ottawa and Allegan Counties. A registered voter must vote at the polling location for his or her own precinct, which is determined by the voter’s address. Check the Ward-Precinct map below to determine your Ward and Precinct.

Election Security

The Ottawa County Clerk’s office has extensive information on how votes are counted and the safety and security of voting in Michigan. Find more information at www.miottawa.org/securingthevote.

Additional Information

For more information about elections or to check your registered voter status online, visit the State of Michigan Voter website and the League of Women Voters website.

Certification of Elections
